This sounds more like a solution. should add more information before this solution,such as:
why people need Inspur NVMe SSD device?(one or two sentence is enough) how people can manage Inspur NVMe SSD device in OpenStack platform if they want to use?
As an operator, I would like to use cyborg to manage Inspur NVMe SSD devices.

Since this will be the first NVMe SSD driver support in Cyborg, hope it can be a good sample for other possible future NVMe SSD drivers for reference. this is still vague, we need more information. Can you specify more like what we did in https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/cyborg-specs/specs/wallaby/approved/vgpu-driver-proposal.html#proposed-changes?

add test report to wiki page.
update doc page and releasenote.

Inspur NVMe SSD devices provides the ability to accelerate VM IO rate.(better add a link to your product page here) In the OpenStack ecosystem, we don't have any tool to manage this kind of accelerators. This spec will add a Inspur NVMe SSD driver in Cyborg to automatically manage Inspur NVMe SSD devices.

The management in the driver scope includes:
* Cyborg Inspur NVMe SSD driver can automatically discover the NVMe SSD and report to database by calling cyborg-conductor. 
* Cyborg Inspur NVMe SSD driver needs to do the device binding/unbounding to VM.(I'm not sure about this. please add this point if your device needs to do something like create mdev in vGPU driver. otherwise just ignore.)
recommend to list points instead of "Firstly, then, finally" , which might be more clear and easier to follow.

suggest adding placement data model like the 3rd point of https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/cyborg-specs/specs/wallaby/approved/vgpu-driver-proposal.html#proposed-changes

And also recommend to mention the configuration of your device if any.
this is not propose something. this is just a configuration.:)

Just the sentence "Add ``SSD`` type to the column device_type in table devices." is enough here.

PS:The second sentence is inaccurate. In the discover process,the Cyborg Agent calls Inspur NVMe SSD driver to collect device information(driver objects), and later calls cyborg-conductor to update the database.
binding a Inspur NVMe SSD to VM

Ah ok, after reading your code, I see the check of vendor ID. It is better to state here, we collect the device not only by grep nvme key works, but also with vendor ID checking.

yeah, NVMe is it's abbreviation.
by grep this keyword and vendor, we can get the vendor's NVMe SSDs.

This configures a 'tags' attribute in the body, and exposes four query parameters: 'tags', 'tags-any', 'not-tags', and 'not-tags-any'. All of these are valid, based on the api-ref [1]. However, it also exposes some methods. 'fetch_tags', 'set_tags' and 'remove_all_tags' want to make GET, PUT and DELETE requests to '/stacks/{stack}/tags' respectively, which does not seem to exist. Likewise, 'check_tag', 'add_tag' and 'remove_tag' want to make GET, PUT and DELETE requests to '/stacks/{stack}/tags/{tag}' respectively, which again does not seem to exist. Given this, does it really make sense to use this mixin or should we just define these attributes ourselves?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/orchestration/v1/index.html?expanded=list-stacks-detail#stacks

This feels like it should be a public attribute given how we're using it in another module, but I assume we can't do that as it would become an attribute of the class. Perhaps we could configure this as an attribute of the 'resource' module, e.g. 'resource.TAG_QUERY_PARAMETERS'? We don't need to fix this now, but it would be a good follow-up.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Doesn't this mean that a new release of pycodestyle can suddenly result in new rules being applied?  I thought this was the reason for having it in test-requirements.

Well, we use pycodestyle via flake8 via hacking.  Each flake8 release specifies pycodestyle in requirements so that only new patch versions of pycodestyle are allowed [0], which supposedly means that there won't be any new checks (just bugfixes) in what flake8 is using.  Since we don't specify flake8 ourselves in test-req, but let hacking constrain it, I figured we would be OK doing the same with pycodestyle.

But ... the patch to master didn't do this, it left pycodestyle==2.6.0 in test-req.  And I re-ran this locally with the new pip resolver and adding pycodestyle back, and there was no problem.

Let me know what you think.  If we do go with the current patch, we should go back and remove pycodestyle pinning from master.  FWIW, nova doesn't specify a pycodestyle version, they just specify hacking.


[0] https://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/faq.html#why-does-flake8-use-ranges-for-its-dependencies

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message: I'm a bit confused by the change - can't you just apply the above change (i.e. use the security group for the tenant_aname instead of the rule) to the original code? Do we need to create the query within the for loop?

We need to have 2 different queries since there can be multiple security groups with different tenant names. If we use just one query we won't get the correct tenant name for all the security group rules in all the security groups.

You're right that we need an additional query. However, I think the group we need to look up is the group that owns the rule. We're looking for all the neutron security group rules that reference this neutron security group as a "remote group". The reason we're doing this is because we have to update the membership of that group, in order to add the fixed IPs from this neutron port. The security group rules in AIM reference remote IPs to do this, and the ACI tenant for the rules in AIM must be in the same ACI tenant as the group in AIM. I think what we want here is to start with the original query (i.e. look for all the neutron security group rules who have a remote group ID that match this neutron security group ID), then iterate through each rule, make another DB query to get the neutron group that owns this rule, then look up that tenant, and use that to make the query for the corresponding rule in AIM. We probably should also keep a cache of neutron security group IDs to tenant IDs, so that we can skip looking up the tenant for a group we've looked up before.
There's an existing function _get_sg_rule_tenant_id where we query the tenant id from the security group the sg rule belongs to instead of the sg rule's tenant id. I have used that function here.

Can we make an optimization here? Since there can be many rules that are referencing this security group as a remote security group, we should use a local dictionary, whose keys are security group UUIDs, and whose values are the tenants for those security groups. Initially the dictionary would be empty, and each time we're trying to get the tenant ID for a security group rule, we'll consult the dictionary first. If it's not in the dictionary, then we'll call _get_sg_rule_tenant_id, so that we can get this using a DB query, and then we add it to the dictionary. This will save us having to make additional DB queries for the same security group (since a SG can have multiple rules in it, each one pointing to this SG as a remote SG), since DB queries are expensive.

For consistency with the others driver schema, the attribute name should use '-' instead of '_'. Also I think we could drop the 're' suffix and document that this accepts a list of regexes.
Why not store them all?  If it's a matter of wanting a limited set of indexes, is there a way to usefully store all the variables in one indexed field?

Yes all variables could be added to the indexed build doc but the usecase that motivate me to write the reporter is not interested by all variables (their base job has around 50 vars). Also an Elasticsearch index is limited (by default) to 1000 fields so I feel safer to allow a selection of fields. We can also set the default to [.*].

Regarding to store all of them in one field by flattening them, that a good point and that possible (using the text type to let Elasticsearch tokenize the field) but after I'm not sure if that will be handy at query time. Or we can do both ? Feedback from Kibana/Elasticsearch experts will be welcome :)

my 2 cents, as will all flattening please be careful, the ir_* variables that we'd like to index under zuul index sometimes are... while still being a string... quite complex by what characters they use, example:

    ir_tripleo_overcloud_deploy_override_options: |-
        --config-heat ComputeExtraConfig.nova::compute::consecutive_build_service_disable_threshold=0 \
        --config-heat OpenDaylightUsername=odladmin \
        --config-heat OpenDaylightPassword=redhat \
        --extra-deploy-params='-e /home/stack/virt/log_levels/netvirt_genius_debug.yaml'

The vars_overwrite doesn't seem consistent with typical Zuul behavior.  I think if a reporter wants to record either the variables or the return data for a build, that's okay.  But I don't think we should have a specific return value that is used to cause the reporter to report incorrect information about the build.  Just have it record returned variables as well (but, report them separately so they don't overlap).
I think we should default to safe defaults, so ssl and verification enabled.
I think it would be cleaner to postfix the tenant name instead of prefixing. This way you have all zuul indexes together when looking at a sorted index list in elasticsearch.

zuul/driver/elasticsearch/connection.py.message:
On the mqtt reporter we have:

  buildset:
    uuid: <uuid>
    builds: []

Is it possible to do the nesting here in the same way? If possible I think we should try to keep the reporting schemas as close together as possible.

Yes it is possible but it will bring complexity when querying the index or building analytic dashboard. I'm not a EL expert but I develop some projects based on EL so I'm quite familiar with the query and schema model. So AFAIK having array of objects (like builds here) will not be convenient if the user want, for instance, to retrieve failed build docs. Indeed the user will get the buildsets docs that match but w/o a way detect the build(s) from the builds array that match the query. Here is a clear explanation: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/nested.html#_how_arrays_of_objects_are_flattened

We can then use the nested objects concept where builds in the array will be real lucene objects but it complexifies the query structure (query and sorting). If a user want to use kibana to query the index it is not going to be convenient as well. See for more info: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/nested.html#nested-fields-array-objects

So to sum up, I'm not for it as I feel a flat schema is far more handy.

Any thoughts @Clark and @Waldemar ?
Do these need to recursively call JSONSerializer.deafault() on d now that it has been sanitized?
Related to the earlier questions about the encoder: do we need a special encoder at all? it seems like we're curating the inputs to elasticsearch in the reporter to exclude this extra info?
This should probably be debug level as we don't need info logs for all the data storage?

If you want to add node information you probably want to use build.nodeset which also contains more information about the nodes.

I'll remove it then. At first glance the sqlreporter and the web UI/Rest API are using that attribute too.
So I'll followup with a patch to propose the removal of build.node_name from Zuul.

ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/api.py.message:
Do you think that doing **columns here, even though there aren't currently any other columns, would be a good choice in case the table is expanded with some optional columns? Then just passing external_ids={'a': 'b', 'x': 'y'} etc.?

I just noticed that the api.py definition of acl_add differs from the impl_idl.py version. The impl  has **external_ids and the api doesn't. Ugh. So you can probably ignore the previous paragraph since the API itself has been kind of silly since I added it. 😞 The shame.

ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands..message:
Let's say may_exist=False and we have an existing row. That means we must fail. Unless I am misreading, it looks like this will try to create a new meter in that case? So it's relying on actually sending the transaction to ovsdb-server and letting it reject it due to a constraint violation?

At least traditionally, the idl C code (and therefor the original ovsdbapp code) would try to avoid sending transactions that it knew were broken w/ may_exist. It's annoying, because it means supporting may_exist means that we always have to do a lookup, even if we would otherwise just be creating an object. In general, I default to whatever ovn-nbctl does, which looks like it locally does the check--but it also doesn't look like it even supports may_exist. Maybe we don't need it then? Or does ovn-nbctl need to be updated to support it?

TBH, I was using 'HAChassisGroupAddCommand' code (above) as a template on how we wanted to handle may_exist. I understand the intent to do whatever ovn-nbctl does, but thought of making
making it a little nicer. ;^)

You are right that nbctl_meter_add currently does not have --may-exist:
https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/blob/f35e33228f6fec97bbecc1f01e28e366d826b585/utilities/ovn-nbctl.c#L2740-L2802
Note: In next rev, I am adding a conditional here to not mess with 'fair', if that is not a column in the existing schema. Please let me know if that is dumb. 😊

It looks like ovn-nbctl meter-del deletes all meters if a name isn't passed. Although we try to default to matching ovn-nbctl as exactly as possible api-wise, I'm sure there are other places where we don't. If you don't think we should match that, I trust your judgement. Just pointing out the difference.

I actually disagree with some choices in the ovn-nbctl code. Like it looks like it is impossible to actually look up a meter by its uuid, just it's name field. I've noticed that in some other ovn-nbctl code as well, which is a departure from how ovs-vsctl did things. Maybe it is a good change as looking up "by name or id" can be ambiguous--but it is a change between the two.

Good points!

I find it both dangerous and unnecessary to use the empty name as a way do delete all meters. Just can't think of a good use case. If you do not mind, let's keep it this way. Note that we have a 'meter_list' in the api, so it should be really simple to have a loop that removes all, if that is really what user wants.

Yeah, the lookup by uuid or name seem to me to be a common thing, agree? So once again I an leaning towards common usage vs a verbatim of what ovn-nbctl provides. I hope I do not live to regret that. ;^)
just a nitty nit: wouldn't be better to write "already exists"?

neutron/db/ovn_revision_numbers_db.py.message:
Ok, now I maybe understand what is happening with this standard_attr_id. This value is assigned by the DB engine because is a "autoincrement" integer.

class StandardAttribute():
    ...
    id = sa.Column(sa.BigInteger().with_variant(sa.Integer(), 'sqlite'),
                   primary_key=True, autoincrement=True)

This value is provided, during a transaction, when the transaction is flushed. That happens in the network DB creation in [1], at the end of this subtransaction context.

If this "id", when the transaction is committed, has been used and deleted, the "id" reference will fail. We need a retry method but I suggest to use oslo_db.api.wrap_db_retry [2]


[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/8d6c301301e33697fd4eb4d6de53f680b909a04d/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L401
[2]We talked about using oslo_db to decorate DB operations https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1887523

nodelabeler/Dockerfile.message:
did some digging. This should be:

  CMD ["/usr/local/bin/nodelabeler"]

Basically, when you use ENTRYPOINT, it's sort of like a shortcut for

  CMD ["/bin/sh", "-c", "<your command>"]

but the scratch image doesn't have /bin/sh. Of course, that also means that you can't get variable expansion, so you have to use the hardcoded path to the binary (although I don't think that's an issue here).

airshipctl's docker image is largely used as a build environment from which we copy the binary. Its dockerfile should probably be changed to match the above.

openstack/cloud/_compute.py.message: Do we really even need _to_munch here? Shouldn't the Resource object behave like a munch since it's a subclass?

It behaves like munch, but it is not munch. That causes weird things on the client side. Additionally in some cases we need original_names, while in others - not. And then, when we have caching we must have munch, otherwise dogpile exits trying to make use of it. I do not like it either, but for consistency we should have it. In the long run (after switching all cloud functions to proxy) we can replace it everywhere, but perhaps breaking our contract (R1.0?)

ceph-osd/templates/bin/osd/ceph-volume/_.message: this is pretty unsafe if not maintained well. Imagine future code that changes data volume naming and if this part is missed - we're going to have an undesired deletion of db or wal volumes. lets hold on for a bit and think if there's another way to bring idempotency to osd-init run
Also, this orphan clean-up behavior used to be in place and the patch set referenced in the commit message broke it. So this also corrects a regression that was introduced a few months back.

In addition to the confusing gate failures we have seen that this seems to fix, there is also a more legitimate case for this logic. If an OSD disk fails and has to be replaced, there isn't currently any logic to remove the failed OSD's DB and WAL volumes automatically if they reside on separate disks. This addresses that and allows for automatic redeployment of the OSD on a new data disk.
